diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: An infectious viral disease causing fever and a red rash, typically occurring in childhood.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection preventable by vaccine and known for its distinctive red rash.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat, characterized by a bright red rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body and is typically associated with fever and redness in the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Zika Virus
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by Zika virus that's spread through mosquito bites, associated with fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, symptoms include fever, joint pain, and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Ehrlichiosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness transmitted by ticks that causes flu-like symptoms, including fever, muscle aches, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks, known for its sudden high fever, severe headache, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus Infection
diagnoses.description: A type of viral infection that can cause a variety of symptoms, including fever, sore throat, pink eye (conjunctivitis), and rash.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to medications that can manifest as rashes, fever, and an elevated white blood cell count.

diagnoses: Drug reactions (e.g., drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if unrelated to other symptoms)
Autoimmune disorders such as Rheumatoid Arthritis or Lupus
Infectious diseases like Tuberculosis or Syphilis
Psychiatric conditions like Schizoaffective Disorder or Bipolar Disorder with psychotic features
Schizophrenia (considering psychosis as primary symptom, and others as comorbid)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis with other systemic symptoms)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Schizophrenia (in rare cases, can present with seizure)

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Symptoms may include skin hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, osteoporosis, easy bruising, and dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, leading to a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy, easy bleeding, and poor healing.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system attacking its own cells and tissues, specifically moisture-producing glands. Common symptoms include dry eyes and mouth, dysautonomias, and lymphadenopathy. It may also lead to more severe complications such as lymphoma.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus causes AIDS, which leads to a severe deterioration in the immune system. Symptoms include lymphadenopathy, weight loss, fever, and an increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections and certain cancers.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins (clotting factors). It can lead to easy bleeding and poor healing after injuries or surgery.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis, can impair the liver's ability to produce clotting factors and to clear hormones leading to dysautonomias, as well as causing poor healing and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. It may cause lymphadenopathy, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell in bone marrow. Patients may suffer from bone pain and brittleness (leading to osteoporosis), frequent infections, easy bleeding, anemia, and impaired kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow with excessive production of ineffective white blood cells. Symptoms include poor healing, easy bleeding, fatigue, fever, and swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy).

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can affect organs and tissues throughout the body. Symptoms vary widely but can include rash, fever, muscle and joint pain, neuropathy, and organ dysfunction.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Leukemia (particularly hairy cell leukemia with monocytosis)

diagnoses.name: Recurrent Pregnancy Loss
diagnoses.description: Recurrent Pregnancy Loss is a condition characterized by two or more failed pregnancies. It can be due to genetic factors, anatomical issues, hormonal imbalances, or immune system disorders. Women with endometriosis often experience higher rates of miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: Endometriosis is a painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. It can cause pain, infertility, and heavy periods, and may be linked to other health issues like immune system disorders.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: PCOS is a hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms include menstrual irregularity, excess hair growth, acne, and obesity. It can lead to serious health issues such as diabetes and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep. Common in people who are overweight, it can lead to daytime fatigue, cardiovascular problems, and other health issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands that make moisture. It most often causes dryness in the mouth and eyes and can affect other parts of the body, including the kidneys, joints, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism's symptoms can vary, with patients often experiencing fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. It can lead to complications if left untreated.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system mistakenly creating antibodies that make your blood much more likely to clot. This condition can lead to recurrent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications.

diagnoses.name: Uterine Fibroids
diagnoses.description: Noncancerous growths of the uterus that often appear during childbearing years. Uterine fibroids can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged periods, pelvic pain, and, in some cases, reproductive problems.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It's associated with a wide range of symptoms, including sleep abnormalities.

diagnoses: Chronic Urticaria (for symptoms similar to angioedema)
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) (could relate with symptoms of endometriosis)
Allergic Rhinitis (can contribute to or exacerbate Sinusitis)
Contact Dermatitis (for skin conditions like warts)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, non-restorative sleep, and potentially lymphadenopathy, which might account for the symptom of lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition of excess parathyroid hormone which can cause increased appetite, osteoporosis, and may contribute to fatigue and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: A disorder that impairs the immune system, potentially leading to recurrent infections such as otitis media, and can also cause non-restorative sleep due to chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.description: In its chronic stage can cause a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenitis, non-restorative sleep, and increased appetite in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by insufficient thyroid hormone production might cause increased appetite and fatigue, and has been associated with osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Although not a direct match for all symptoms, uncontrolled diabetes can cause increased appetite and fatigue. Otitis media can be more common in individuals with poorly controlled diabetes due to weakened immunity.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: Different types of anemia can result in non-restorative sleep and increased appetite, and chronic anemia can impact overall health including susceptibility to infections like otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs, sarcoidosis can cause lymphadenitis, fatigue, and has been associated with hypercalcemia leading to osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, celiac disease can cause non-restorative sleep, osteoporosis due to malabsorption, and increased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness that can cause a variety of symptoms, including fatigue (non-restorative sleep), lymphadenopathy (similar in effect to lymphadenitis), and potentially joint complications resembling osteoporosis if left untreated.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling. Aura symptoms might include disturbances like speech and language (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke can cause symptoms such as paralysis or loss of muscle movement, difficulty speaking or understanding speech (aphasia), and headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Brain tumors can cause a variety of symptoms based on their location. These can include headaches that may be more severe in the morning, nausea, vomiting, and problems with speech including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty concentrating. Aphasia could develop in severe cases or in meningitis affecting specific brain regions.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.details: A brain aneurysm is a bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and symptoms of stroke such as difficulties with speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.details: Also known as giant cell arteritis, this is an inflammatory disease affecting large and medium arteries. Symptoms can include severe headaches, jaw pain, and vision problems. While aphasia directly is less common, it can occur if the inflammation leads to stroke.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Encephalopathy
diagnoses.details: A condition caused by severely high blood pressure that leads to brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure causing headaches, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness, and possibly aphasia if areas governing speech are affected.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.details: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The cause is often an infection. Symptoms can include severe headache, nausea, fever, confusion and, in serious cases, seizures and speech problems (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the central nervous system that can affect the brain and spinal cord. It can cause problems with vision, balance, muscle control, and other basic body functions. Headache isn’t a common symptom, but nausea and language difficulties (aphasia) can occur during MS exacerbations.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Common symptoms can include headache, aphasia, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura includes visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear before the headache and last for about 20 to 60 minutes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells start to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden headache, confusion, trouble speaking, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It often looks like a berry hanging on a stem. A brain aneurysm can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms may include headaches that are typically worse in the morning, nausea, vomiting, speech difficulties, and others.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Meningitis can result from viral, bacterial, fungal, and other infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by acute or chronic high blood pressure leading to brain dysfunction. Symptoms include severe headache, nausea, vomiting, convulsions, confusion, and coma.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST)
diagnoses.description: A rare form of stroke. It occurs when a blood clot forms in the brain's venous sinuses. This prevents blood from draining out of the brain. As a result, blood cells may break and leak blood into the brain tissues, forming a hemorrhage.

diagnoses: DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
